review.title: Dimensionality Invariant Similarity Measure
review.abstract: This paper presents a new similarity measure to be used for general tasks including supervised learning, which is represented by the K-nearest neighbor classifier (KNN). The proposed similarity measure is invariant to large differences in some dimensions in the feature space. The proposed metric is proved mathematically to be a metric. To test its viability for different applications, the KNN used the proposed metric for classifying test examples chosen from a number of real datasets. Compared to some other well known metrics, the experimental results show that the proposed metric is a promising distance measure for the KNN classifier with strong potential for a wide range of applications.

sections.text: A similarity measurement is a function that reflects a non-negative number to each pair of vectors in which the neighbors resemble each other (Hagedoorn 2000).Such a measurement is crucial for a wide range of applications and research areas, including - but not limited to - pattern matching algorithms, artificial intelligence (Hagedoorn 2000), machine learning (He, Chen and Chen 2013), regression analysis (Wessela and Schork 2006) and data mining (Geng and Hamilton 2006), in addition to other areas of research such as social science, economics, zero theory testing, etc. Similarity measurements are required in almost all scientific disciplines.A large number of similarity measurements are proposed in the literature, perhaps the most well-known and best-known being the distance indicated by Euclid two thousand years ago. Great efforts have been made in the last century to find new metrics and similarities to satisfy the needs of different applications.

sections.text: As shown in Table 2, the proposed distance has achieved good results that exceed the other distances in 10 datasets, and the overall average accuracy is the best of all the distances tested. As expected, the lowest accuracies were recorded by Eq (1) due to the problems with Eq (1) already mentioned. For example, the accuracy of Eq (1) on Vowel, Segments and Waveform40 are 7.30%, 14.20% and 38.10%. The reason for this low performance is due to the data used on these datasets, which contain real numbers, see Table 1), while Eq (1) is not well defined in negative values.
